He was sitting straight on a chair, totally still. His serious face showed no emotion, legs stretched out—heels together, toes pointed out. 

He listened to his mom talking to his sister, lips pouting and eyes wide open, just like good little boys do when they’re getting ready for bed. A younger girl, dressed in rags, stood by the screen, waiting for her turn. The door to the stairs was open to let some fresh air in, trying to push back the clouds of tobacco smoke from the other rooms. That smoke made the sick woman cough hard. Katerina Ivanovna looked even thinner this week, and her face was flushed.

“You wouldn’t believe how good we had it back in my dad's house, Polenka,” she said, pacing the room. “This drunkard has ruined everything for us! My dad was a civil colonel, almost a governor. Everyone who visited would say, ‘We see you as our governor!’ When I… when…” She coughed violently, “Oh, cursed life!” she exclaimed, pressing her hands to her chest. “When I… at the last ball… at the marshal’s… Princess Bezsemelnaya, who blessed your father and me, asked right away, ‘Isn’t that the pretty girl who danced at the breaking-up?’” (You need to fix that tear; grab your needle.)

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Katerina Ivanovna reflects on her past luxurious life and laments the ruin brought upon her family by her husband's alcoholism.
